name: Lankshorn
tagline: High Wold market town on the edge of the tangled, breggle-ruled woods
description: A bustling town of well-kept, stonebuilt houses, clustered around a tall-steepled church and a cobbled market square. At the rear of the town, a slope rises towards Dolmenwood, which looms ominously, a reminder of Lankshorn's position on the verge of the wild.
atmosphere: Bustling but ominous, positioned on the edge of the wild
inhabitants_description: Mostly consisting of local, curly-haired folk of High Woldish origin who have made their livings in the town for many generations. A number of breggles also dwell in Lankshorn.

governance.ruling_body: Lord Malbleat and Berkmaster Baldricke—Malbleat's representative in the town (a mayor of sorts)
governance.political_status: Part of Lord Malbleat's newly established domain
governance.notes: Twenty-two years ago, Lankshorn was wrested overnight from the domain of Lord Ramius and became part of the newly established domain of Lord Malbleat

religion.religious_practices: The people of Lankshorn are devout followers of the Pluritine Church. However, in addition to the tenets of the Church, Lankshorners proudly follow a body of local superstitions.
religion.notes: Ancient Gwyrae beliefs blend with the strictures of the Pluritine Church, forming an idiosyncratic mass of folk belief and superstition

history: Lankshorn lies within a bowshot of the forest's border, acting as one of the two main 'thresholds' into Dolmenwood
Twenty-two years ago, a feud among the nobles of House Ramius led to an abrupt reshaping of traditional domain boundaries in the High Wold
Lankshorn was wrested overnight from the domain of Lord Ramius and became part of the newly established domain of Lord Malbleat
Over many generations, the humans and breggles of Lankshorn have partially intermixed
current_events: Malbleat's increasingly brazen cruelty is leading to unrest in Lankshorn
Some folk speak of petitioning the Baron Hogwarsh to intervene and replace Malbleat or restore Lankshorn to the domain of Lord Ramius

special_features.name: Breggle Blood
special_features.description: Over many generations, the humans and breggles of Lankshorn have partially intermixed. Most Lankshorners show no evidence of this mixed heritage, but the occasional goat-like feature can be noted among the human townsfolk.
special_features.mechanical_effect: Roll d6 for goatish aspects: 1-Goatee beard, 2-Goat eyes, 3-Goat's hoof foot, 4-Goat's hoof hand, 5-Horn nubs on forehead, 6-Rudimentary tail

special_features.name: Lankshorn Superstitions
special_features.description: Ancient Gwyrae beliefs blend with the strictures of the Pluritine Church, forming an idiosyncratic mass of folk belief and superstition. PCs who transgress these edicts encounter an incredulous or frosty reception from locals.
special_features.mechanical_effect: Transgressing superstitions causes frosty reception from locals

special_items: Mounts and hounds usually only available at market on Moot
equipment_availability.notes: Mounts and hounds are usually only available at the market on Moot

locations.name: Church of St Pastery
locations.description: An antique, stone church with a strikingly pointy steeple and a riot of carvings depicting gargoyles and angels battling.
locations.interior: In contrast with the church's grand exterior, the interior is simple and rustic: lacquered wooden pews, a stone block altar, and a 5′-high wooden statue of St Pastery (patron saint of butchers and well-borers) holding a meat cleaver and a shovel.
locations.exterior: An archway lined with white marble carvings of a friar (St Pastery) laying hands beneficently on hordes of cattle.
locations.populace: Solemn mourners and supplicants, cheery choirs. The local vicar, Father Eggwin Dobey, surreptitiously surveying visitors from a balcony. On Sunning mornings, most of the townsfolk attend the sermon.
locations.atmosphere: Simple and rustic despite grand exterior

services.name: Prayer
services.description: Characters praying may receive the blessing of St Pastery: the ability to cast Cure Affliction

special_features: Secret passage to the woods: A trapdoor is concealed beneath a stone font. Beneath, a short flight of stairs leads down to a damp tunnel that passes beneath Lankshorn and emerges in the woods in hex 0709, close to the Manor Road.
secrets: Father Dobey uses this tunnel to come and go between Lankshorn and Redwraith Manor

locations.name: Market Square
locations.description: A cobbled market square at the centre of the town. Markets are held here twice a week:

services.name: Moot Market
services.description: Food, drink, and livestock market. Stalls hawking local produce, freshly brewed cider, and a vast array of cheeses. Horses and hounds of all kinds may also be purchased on Moot.

services.name: Sunning Market
services.description: General market with a mixture of stalls

locations.name: Vicarage
locations.description: A small, thatched cottage located to the south-east of the town proper, accessed by a track that winds through sheep-grazed pastures.
locations.populace: The local vicar, Father Dobey, along with his maidservant, Mabble.

locations.name: Graveyard
locations.description: To the rear of the vicarage lies the village's graveyard, bounded by imposing, ivy-clad walls.
locations.interior: Graveyard with goats' heads carved atop many gravestones
locations.exterior: Cast iron gates engraved with Liturgic script. The writing is a traditional plea to Saint Signis the Silent that the interred dead may slumber in rest eternal.
special_features: To anyone familiar with religious practices within Dolmenwood, it is clear that the graveyard is under the protection of the order of Lichwards

locations.name: The Hornstoat's Rest
locations.description: A high-gabled, wooden building of overhanging eaves and many-hued, lacquered panels. A wide, round door topped with a goat's skull welcomes travellers and merrymakers.
locations.interior: A cramped room with high stools crammed against the walls and a cluster of three small tables in the centre. In the late evenings: The tables are often pushed together in the centre of the common room and used as an improvised stage for raucous dances or musical performances.
locations.exterior: Sign: A white stoat with prominent red horns reclining on a luxurious purple couch.
locations.populace: Guests are served by the landlady, Margerie Stallowmade, her three sons, and her twelve-year-old daughter Willow (who has a goat's hoof in place of her left hand). Guests: Local folk, pedlars, travellers, and merchants. There is a 2-in-6 chance per evening of a beloved Lankshorn resident—the sage Farnham Ribblemead (who rents the inn's attic suite on a permanent basis)—quietly sharing a glass of Aspintheon with the landlady.
locations.atmosphere: Cramped but lively, with evening entertainment

services.name: Aspintheon
services.description: The preferred tipple of the proprietor, Purple Aspintheon is always in stock. Favoured guests may also be offered a glass of the rarer and more infamous Green Aspintheon.

special_features: The attic suite: A heavy, locked door in the inn's upper floor leads, via a steep, creaky stairway, to a plush attic suite—the home of the sage Farnham Ribblemead.

locations.name: Harper's Hall
locations.description: A tall, lime-white manor beside a shallow lake ringed with storm-wracked elms.
locations.interior: Town residence of Lord Malbleat, with one side-wing housing the Berkmaster and his family
locations.exterior: Tall, lime-white manor beside a shallow lake
locations.populace: The current Berkmaster (installed by Malbleat when he assumed lordship of the town) is Clewyd Baldricke ('His Lordship'), who lives here with his wife Almerie and four adolescent children.
special_features: Harper's Hall serves a dual purpose. First and foremost, it is the town residence of Lord Malbleat, though he seldom inhabits it for longer than a night each month. Secondly, one of its side-wings houses the Berkmaster and his family.
secrets: Hidden fugitive: The Berkmaster harbours his grandson—a rebellious young half-human, half-breggle boy named Billy—who stumbled out of the Wood some months ago. The boy fled from Redwraith Manor after his governess fed him a dangerous mandrake brew as punishment. The brew afflicted the boy with a curse, causing him to mutate into different forms and personalities.

locations.name: The Bladesmith
locations.description: A slate-roofed, pebble-walled forge with tall chimney of stacked slate. The resident blacksmith, Joremey Whilpston-Puddingfoot, earns his daily living shoeing horses, mending pots, and forging farm tools. His true passion, however, is for the forging of artisan blades.
locations.exterior: Slate-roofed, pebble-walled forge with tall chimney
locations.atmosphere: Working forge focused on quality craftsmanship

services.name: Standard blades
services.description: Finely crafted steel blades at 25% above the normal price

services.name: Iron blades
services.description: A small number of iron daggers are kept in stock at all times

services.name: Silvering
services.description: Silvered daggers and swords may be purchased at ten times the cost of a plain steel blade. Only silvered daggers are usually kept in stock.

services.name: Engraving
services.description: Commissioned blades may be engraved with patterns, script, or runes, as the buyer wishes. This typically doubles the basic cost. The bladesmith's work is detailed and beautiful.

services.name: Moon-forging
services.description: The bladesmith is privy to a craft of fairy origin—practiced by very few in the modern day—by which a blade forged by the light of the full moon can be imbued with a minor enchantment. Moon-forging takes much preparation and is only performed to special order for trusted customers.

special_features: His handiwork is of a quality seldom found even in great towns

locations.name: The Man of Gold Apothecary
locations.description: A squat, stone building with a wooden, two-storey tower lies in a narrow alleyway at the rear of the Hornstoat's Rest, cramped between a fishmonger's and a butchery.
locations.interior: Apothecary shop with herbs carefully air-dried in the tower above
locations.exterior: Sign: The sign of a smiling, golden sun swings above the door, announcing the name and function of this shop.

services.name: Mushrooms and herbs
services.description: The preparations listed in the Dolmenwood Player's Book are sold at the standard prices and with the standard chance of availability

services.name: Alchemical compounds
services.description: 2-in-6 chance of each being in stock: Alchemical Tonic, Amber Nectar, Memory Dust, Orgon's Scintillating Philtre

services.name: Psychedelic compounds
services.description: 2-in-6 chance of each being in stock: Black Clover, Devil's Grease, Frisk, Lethe

special_features: The establishment has been in the Maldwort family for three generations and has an excellent reputation for the quality of its herbs

locations.name: The Nuncle-Stones
locations.description: A ring of ancient, moss-covered stones standing upon a hill, looming over the town.
locations.exterior: Ring of ancient, moss-covered stones on a hill
locations.populace: The townsfolk shun the stones, believing them to be associated with the dark magic of the Drune. The stones are therefore a favoured haunt of local youths, daring to defy their elders' wisdom.
locations.atmosphere: Shunned and mysterious, favored by rebellious youth
special_features: Swirling vortex: Anyone who can detect magic or the invisible (e.g. those under the influence of Green Aspintheon, p426) perceives a swirling pink and orange vortex in the sky above the stones. Anyone who flies into the vortex is swept away by a violent gust of wind and released half an hour later above the Isle of Yeth (hex 0505).

locations.name: The Ditchway
locations.description: The east-west road, known to locals as the Ditchway, winds through a broad channel with sandy banks on either side. The western route is disused, as it passes by the haunted Lankston Pool (hex 0610), but the eastern road is frequented by much trade, leading to the port-town Dreg on the banks of the Hameth (hex 1110).
locations.exterior: East-west road through broad channel with sandy banks
locations.atmosphere: Western route haunted and disused, eastern route busy with trade
special_features: To the Trothstone: An old path leads into the forest from the western road out of Lankshorn. Those who follow the path come to a glade (hex 0609) where, according to tradition, weddings of longhorn nobles take place.

locations.name: Manor Road
locations.description: The old north road leads to the gates of Lord Malbleat's estate at Redwraith Manor (hex 0709). Beyond the Malbleat's manor, a track known as Fisher's Path leads to the depths of Dwelmfurgh and Lake Longmere in the heart of the Wood.
locations.exterior: North road leading to Redwraith Manor
locations.populace: Travelers to and from the manor

locations.name: Swallop Road
locations.description: A hedge-lined country road winds through rustic farmland towards High-Hankle.

locations.name: Bogway's
locations.description: A ramshackle two-storey drinking establishment with wonky windows. A large stable yard and stalls are located at the rear.
locations.interior: A lofty space, packed with wobbly tables and stumpy stools. Balconies on the upper floor overlook the common room. An iron candelabra bearing dozens of fat candles hangs from chains in the rafters, occasionally dripping gouts of wax onto patrons below. Upper rooms: A bustling and inconveniently low-roofed dancehall and a series of gloomy side-rooms for card games or discreet liaisons.
locations.exterior: Sign: A grinning toad holding a frothing mug of ale.
locations.populace: The proprietors, Lump 'Sarge' Groghorn and Whimsly Bobblefrock, serve the crowds from behind a row of barrels. Guests: A raucous mix of human and shorthorn farm hands, wayfarers, drunkards, and gamblers.

services.name: Food
services.notes: No lodgings available (apart from stabling for mounts)

services.name: Nippers
services.description: The grimalkin's favoured tipple, Nippers is always available here

services.name: Stabling
services.description: Despite the low cost, the stables at Bogway's are of good quality and the grooms are well-trained and professional

services.name: Horses
services.description: Good quality riding horses can often be purchased from the stables at the normal price

npcs.name: Father Eggwin Dobey
npcs.title: Vicar of Lankshorn
npcs.description: The vicar of Lankshorn is a scrawny, stooped human man of advanced years with a wispy pate and flimsy spectacles.
npcs.mannerisms: Has a habit of wagging his finger admonishingly
npcs.speech: Feeble, wavering. Woldish, Liturgic, Old Woldish.
desires: To aid Lord Malbleat in defeating his half-brother Lord Ramius and consolidating his rule over all of the High Wold
To be instated as the Archdeacon of High-Hankle
secrets: Dobey is a corrupt priest who cares little for the Church. He serves Lord Malbleat and is complicit in several of his wicked schemes.

known_topics.content: Father Dobey wags his finger. 'Welcome to the Church of St Pastery, patron of butchers and well-borers. Blessings upon those who seek them.'
He nods knowingly. 'The folk of Lankshorn have their own customs, you see. Ancient beliefs mingled with proper faith. Wise visitors respect our ways.'

secret_info.content: Dobey is a corrupt priest who serves Lord Malbleat and is complicit in several of his wicked schemes. He cares little for the Church itself.
secret_info.hint: He speaks of Lord Malbleat with unusual deference and avoids criticizing the lord's cruelty.

secret_info.content: Dobey uses a secret tunnel beneath the church to travel between Lankshorn and Redwraith Manor unseen.
secret_info.hint: He sometimes arrives at the church looking travel-worn despite claiming to have been in his vicarage.

faction_profile.cover_story: A humble vicar devoted to his flock

triggers.npc_response: Ah, friends of His Lordship. Come, let us speak privately.
I sense... divided loyalties. Be careful in Lankshorn.

npcs.name: Margerie Stallowmade
npcs.title: Hornstoat's Rest Landlady
npcs.description: A human woman of some fifty years, with twinkling eyes, a broad grin, copper hoops in her ears, and a figure plump with decades of pie-eating.
demeanor: presents herself to strangers as a harmless bumpkin
has a keen ear and a sharp memory
npcs.mannerisms: Constantly polishes surfaces, mugs, and guests while chatting
desires: To meet a real witch or wizard
To taste the legendary Golden Aspintheon
secrets: Since the death of her husband and two eldest sons in a pointless war a decade ago, Margerie has taken to wandering in Dolmenwood, fascinated by its strange secrets

She is acquainted with the fairy Thrattlewhit (hex 0810), with whom she shares foraged blackberries and silly stories of comings and goings in Lankshorn. She knows the location of the fairy's lair, but does not share it lightly.

known_topics.content: Margerie beams while polishing. 'Welcome to the Hornstoat's Rest! Lodging, food, and the finest Aspintheon in all the High Wold. Purple's always in stock—and if you're special, maybe Green.'
Her eyes sparkle. 'The Wood holds such wonders... I've walked its paths, you know. Met creatures most folk only dream of. Real witches and wizards—I'd love to meet one!'

secret_info.content: Margerie is acquainted with the fairy Thrattlewhit in hex 0810. She knows the fairy's lair location but doesn't share it lightly.
secret_info.hint: She occasionally disappears into the woods with baskets of blackberries.

relationships.description: Rents the attic suite to the sage and shares quiet drinks with him

npcs.name: Farnham Ribblemead
npcs.title: Sage
npcs.description: An elderly human gentleman of gangly frame, with long white hair, hawkish nose, wide mouth, and stretched, angular cheeks. Wears shabby leather traveller's garb and a pair of half-moon spectacles balanced on his nose.
npcs.dress: shabby leather traveller's garb and a pair of half-moon spectacles
npcs.speech: Lethargic drawl. Woldish, Old Woldish, Liturgic, Caprice, Gaffe, Old Drunic, Sylvan, Drunic.
desires: Access to Malbleat's library, said to contain a large body of texts in Old Caprice

known_topics.content: Farnham peers through half-moon spectacles. 'Languages, scripts, ancient texts—my specialty. I speak eight tongues fluently. What mysteries do you bring?'
He leans forward eagerly. 'Lord Malbleat's library... rumored to contain texts in Old Caprice. If only I could gain access...'

relationships.description: Rents the attic suite and shares quiet evenings with the landlady

npcs.name: Berkmaster Clewyd Baldricke
npcs.title: Berkmaster
npcs.description: A tall, plump human man of around 50 years, with densely curled, auburn hair on his head, face, and chest. He dresses in voluptuous purple velvet and wears the silver boar's head medallion hereditary to his station.
npcs.dress: voluptuous purple velvet and wears the silver boar's head medallion hereditary to his station
demeanor: incredulous at any who would question his word
desires: The respect of all in Lankshorn
To cure his grandson Billy of his curse
To temper the wickedness of Lord Malbleat
secrets: Privately worries that his lord's growing cruelty will lead to rebellion
Many townsfolk privately mock the Berkmaster as a self-important puppet of Lord Malbleat

known_topics.content: Baldricke booms pompously. 'I am Berkmaster of Lankshorn, His Lordship's representative! All matters of governance pass through me.'
His voice drops with genuine worry. 'My grandson... a good lad, truly. If only there were someone skilled in curing... unusual afflictions.'

secret_info.content: The Berkmaster harbors his grandson Billy—a half-human, half-breggle boy cursed to mutate into different forms after his governess fed him a dangerous mandrake brew at Redwraith Manor.
secret_info.hint: He occasionally glances toward a particular wing of Harper's Hall with anxious concern.

secret_info.content: Baldricke privately worries that Malbleat's growing cruelty will lead to rebellion. Many townsfolk mock him as a self-important puppet.
secret_info.hint: He flinches when 'MALBLEAT OUT!' graffiti is mentioned.

triggers.npc_response: His Lordship has his ways. I... serve as I must.

npcs.name: Joremey Whilpston-Puddingfoot
npcs.title: Bladesmith
npcs.description: A slim human man in his late forties, with black, slicked-back hair and eyes set wide apart.
demeanor: easily waxes lyrical when speaking of his craft
npcs.speech: Gentle, lilting quality. Woldish, basic Sylvan.
desires: To know the identity of his fairy ancestor
To forge a sword for the Duke of Brackenwold
secrets: Unbeknown to any in the town, Joremey has fairy blood—his grandfather was sired by a wandering elf

known_topics.content: Joremey holds your gaze calmly. 'Steel blades, iron daggers, silvered weapons—I craft them all. My work is of a quality seldom found even in great towns.'
His eyes light up with passion. 'Moon-forging... an ancient craft of fairy origin. I can imbue blades with enchantments, for trusted customers who understand such arts.'
He gazes wistfully at his finest work. 'To forge a sword for the Duke of Brackenwold himself... that is my greatest dream.'

secret_info.content: Joremey has fairy blood—his grandfather was sired by a wandering elf. He desperately wishes to know the identity of this fairy ancestor.
secret_info.hint: He speaks Sylvan and knows fairy crafting techniques that should be beyond a mortal smith.

npcs.name: Sydewich Maldwort
npcs.title: Man of Gold Proprietor
npcs.description: A human bachelor in his late thirties, with a fashionable moustache and long blond hair tied in plaits.
demeanor: excited to converse with folk of adventurous spirit
desires: To sell the apothecary and elope with Elmine Crump, wife of the keeper of the Spawning Salmon tavern in Dreg, whom he is in love with

known_topics.content: Sydewich's voice is nasal and oily. 'Herbs, mushrooms, alchemical compounds... The Man of Gold has served Lankshorn for three generations. What do you require?'
His eyes brighten. 'Adventurers! Finally, folk of spirit. Tell me of your travels—the simple townsfolk here bore me to tears.'

secret_info.content: Sydewich is in love with Elmine Crump, wife of the keeper of the Spawning Salmon tavern in Dreg. He dreams of selling the apothecary and eloping with her.
secret_info.hint: He frequently travels to Dreg on 'business' and speaks wistfully of the port-town.

npcs.name: Lump "Sarge" Groghorn
npcs.title: Bogway's Proprietor
npcs.description: An ageing, battle-scarred, white-eyed shorthorn man dressed in grimy leather with a single gold earring.
npcs.dress: grimy leather with a single gold earring
desires: To marry a 'real lady' (i.e. a longhorn)
To steal Lord Murkin's enchanted sword
secrets: Served in Lord Murkin's army for many years

known_topics.content: Sarge scowls meanly, then laughs heartily. 'Food, drink, stabling—Bogway's has it all. No fancy lodgings, but the horses are treated like royalty.'
He pulls his ear thoughtfully. 'Lord Murkin's enchanted sword... I served in his army for years. That blade should be mine by rights.'

secret_info.content: Sarge served in Lord Murkin's army for many years and knows intimate details of longhorn military tactics and the layout of Murkin's holdings.
secret_info.hint: He occasionally uses military terminology and speaks of 'the old days' with bitterness.

faction_profile.cover_story: Just a humble tavern keeper now

npcs.name: Whimsly Bobblefrock
npcs.title: Bogway's Proprietor
npcs.description: A gangly tortoiseshell grimalkin woman who habitually wears a tricorn hat and an eyepatch.
npcs.speech: Purring punctuated with yowls. Woldish, Mewl, Gaffe.
desires: To relieve the arrogant rich of their baubles
secrets: Escaped imprisonment for gambling debts in Chateau Shantywood (hex 1110) with the aid of a sympathetic bard
An Eye of the Yurl (p420), hidden beneath her eyepatch

known_topics.content: Whimsly purrs indignantly. 'Bogway's welcomes all—grimalkin, shorthorn, human alike. We judge by coin, not kindred.'
She yowls with flamboyance. 'The arrogant rich deserve to be relieved of their baubles, wouldn't you say? I know folk who... arrange such things.'

secret_info.content: Whimsly escaped imprisonment for gambling debts in Chateau Shantywood with the aid of a sympathetic bard. She dreams of burning the chateau down.
secret_info.hint: She hisses whenever Shantywood Isle or Dreg is mentioned.

secret_info.content: Hidden beneath her eyepatch is an Eye of the Yurl—a magical artifact.
secret_info.hint: She never removes her eyepatch, even when bathing.

entries.description: 3d6 shorthorn (DMB) soldiers bringing a caged captive to Redwraith Manor for trial before Lord Malbleat.
A company of 2d6 merchants (plus their guards—DMB) from Castle Brackenwold.
A funeral procession of 3d6 townsfolk wearing wooden goat masks, led by Father Dobey (p158).
Lord Malbleat (p64) and 2d4 longhorn (DMB) guards demanding impromptu taxes (10% of carried wealth).
Sydewich Maldwort (p160) haggling with a loud foreign pedlar over the price of Memory Dust (p426).
1d4 masked townsfolk furtively daubing "MALBLEAT OUT!" on walls.
Father Dobey (p158) sneaking into the woods, via the secret passage in the church, to meet with a minion of Lord Malbleat.
Lord Malbleat (p64), 2d4 shorthorn (DMB) guards, and 1d4 longhorn (DMB) nobles driving in a fancy carriage to the Hornstoat's Rest to demand food and entertainment.
Margerie Stallowmade (p159) gossiping with a barrowbogey (DMB) from hex 0810.
